The latest Decouple podcast, Australia’s Nuclear Debate, is as much about fairly modelling an All-Renewable future grid as it is about the 2025 Australian election which the centre-right Liberals, currently out of power, are framing as a referendum on nuclear. I was surprised to learn that the rooftop solar feed-in tariffs have stalled the growth of grid-scale solar. State Capacity Libertarians like Tyler need to reconcile their support for nuclear with the significant state financial support that seems to be a prerequisite for high-CapEx/long-life mega projects like nuclear and hydroelectric generation, ditto greenfield transmission.

I hope Crikey listens or (YouTube) watches the conversation. I'm not sure that the price advantage of renewables is as stark as his renewables+coal loving mates believe. Accurately modelling the future integrated electrical system (i.e. the grid) is non-trivial, IMO, and we should work on building shared models that all stakeholders can use to promote their positions. YMMV.

BTW, I think the Ontario IESO models are facile. I'm hoping that the Aussies and/or Yanks set an example that Ontario's planners can follow.

item.title: Comment on Austin Vernon on emissions reduction (from my email) by Not that I doubt your numbers
item.description:
Reply to PHinton:

There was an excellent article on RealClear in the past few weeks. It was good because it gave us another peek from professionals that are tasked with providing reliable power to consumers.

This was a coalition of engineers working at providers for mid-atlantic region. They expect demand to increase 40% in the next 15 years. That's 2.3% YoY.

What is interesting is another group of engineers focused on the midwest grids see a lot of coal retiring. But for every MW of coal that retires, you don't just replace it with a MW of solar. Instead 1 MW of coal must be replaced with 4.2 MW of wind, or a staggering 21.4 MW of fixed solar.

So, when we see people saying "Oh, look the levelized cost of solar is better than coal!" and I reply "Yes, but that ignores the intermittency aspect. Solar must be substantially overbuilt to deliver the same utility as coal. That means you need a solar farm, backed by batteries, backed by gas peaking plants"

We now know that you need 21MW of solar to replace 1 MW of coal. And at those numbers, the math doesn't work.

I often wonder why people that believe solar is cheaper than coal wonder why anyone is still building coal. In the US they might argue it's because of "big coal." But China doesn't have those concerns. And they are building coal plants left and right. Solar yes. But mostly coal. And why? Because the math on solar doesn't work. And if you need 21MW of solar to replace a MW of coal, suddenly it should be clear to all.

Perish the very thought.

However, Germany is currently burning less coal for electricity generation than before nuclear power was available for electricity generation. Checking the ever useful numbers at www energy-charts info, in July 2014 Germany was using coal to generate 30GW of electricity. Same week in 2024, coal is used to generate about 8GW.

Yet somehow, Germany did not actually install 400GW of solar capacity. In part, of course, because anyone able to run a stable grid with higher reliability than America's uses a mix of generation sources. The real numbers for Germany seem to be a total installed capacity amounting to 81.8 gigawatts at the end of 2023.

Doubt is not the right term concerning your numbers, but that is the way to go with whatever you present as reality. Not that anyone ever expects you to check the information you so easily repeat here.

Sometimes, one gets the feeling that even TC is a bit embarrassed, like the fate of that thread on Trump's lying.

item.title: Comment on Claims about Anchorage (from the comments) by Nitpicking
item.description:
Anchorage is not the busiest cargo airport in the world, it's the 4th busiest behind Hong Kong, Memphis, and Shanghai (though the airport's manager quips "We are the busiest airport in the world that nothing comes from or goes to," which very well may be true). The reason it's so busy in the first place was because it was approximately near the great circle route that most airplanes took between east Asia and the US, and was midway through. Planes didn't have as much range back then (and ETOPS hadn't been introduced), so they had to stop in Anchorage to refuel. Cargo planes sacrifice range for cargo tonnage, so they still to this day stop in Anchorage to refuel when flying between North America and east Asia.

However, they do NOT stop in Anchorage when flying between east Asia and Europe. That's the complete wrong direction. For example, flying from Shanghai to London is ~9300km directly. Stopping in Anchorage first adds another 5000km to the route (7000km from Shanghai to Anchorage, 7200km from Anchorage to London). As far as I can tell, most China-Europe air freight flies direct.

If the argument is "Anchorage is near the Bering Strait so it will see a lot of cargo pass through it," that seems to me silly. Cargo vessels can stay at sea for weeks at a time, even the largest ones, so they wouldn't need to come into port in Anchorage to resupply like cargo planes do. They would just carry on to China or Korea or wherever. That being said, the proximity to all that shipping makes it an obvious location for a major US naval presence.
